author: TN World Desk
title: Tornado In Bunbury, Australia Connected To US Storm Spree? AI Says... | Times Now
text: A tornado ripped through Bunbury in Western Australia, about 150 kms south of Perth, on Friday. Local media reports and residents of the city said that the twister caused severe damage to property and wrecked a community centre where at least 50 children were present. This comes as the United States is battling severe thunderstorm weather and tornadoes for over a month now. Several US states, including Michigan, Texas, Florida, Nebraska, Ohio, Iowa, have been affected by tornadoes. Damage to property and injuries have been reported. As Australia witnessed a massive tornado on Friday afternoon, several social media users asked if the bad weather is connected to the storm spree in the United States. Read More: Jackson Tornado: Mississippi On Alert, Warnings In Bolton And ClintonWe decided to ask Google's Gemini. When asked 'Can tornadoes in the US cause tornadoes in Australia?' - the chatbot said: \"No, a tornado in the US cannot directly cause a tornado in Australia. Tornadoes are local phenomena that depend on specific atmospheric conditions in their immediate area.\"It further listed reasons, saying the massive distance between the two countries would make it impossible. Here's where we tried to understand the weather and wind patterns. When asked, 'if weather in the United States influence the weather in Australia?', Google's Gemini said: \"Yes, to a certain extent, weather in the US can influence weather in Australia, but not in the way a single event like a tornado can directly cause another.\"Read More: San Marcos Tornado: Texas City On Alert, Warning Issued In AustinThe chatbot added that the movement of 'air masses around the globe can influence weather patterns in distant locations. For instance, the El NiÃ±o-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) impacts both the US and Australia'.However, it is important to note that the influence of US weather on Australia is indirect. Hence, the Bunbury tornado was likely not influenced by the storm spree in the United States.

author: @andaluciainf
title: El Athletic hunde al LeganÃ©s bajo el diluvio | AndalucÃ­a InformaciÃ³n. Noticias de Torremolinos
text: El Athletic de Bilbao saliÃ³ victorioso de su visita a LeganÃ©s (0-2), un duelo disputado bajo un intenso diluvio del que escapÃ³ sin ahogarse gracias al acierto reflejado por el gol de Dani Vivian que desviÃ³ Jorge SÃ¡enz, y el de IÃ±aki Williams mientras los intentos del cuadro madrileÃ±o se topaban con los palos. La que iba a ser, aparentemente, una tranquila, y poco habitual en Butarque, tarde de fÃºtbol entre semana, tornÃ³ en caÃ³tica cuando media hora antes del inicio del choque comenzÃ³ a desplegarse sobre el estadio y sus inmediaciones una densa cortina de agua, como hacÃ­a muchos aÃ±os que no se recordaba. Debido a ello se complicÃ³ el aparcamiento y el acceso de los aficionados al recinto; se inundÃ³ una parte de los pupitres destinados al trabajo de la prensa; y la zona descubierta de la grada, tres cuartos de la misma, luciÃ³ casi vacÃ­a con el pitido de salida. Los problemas fueron poco a poco solucionÃ¡ndose y al cuarto de hora, cuando comenzÃ³ a salir el sol, la sensaciÃ³n era la de que no habÃ­a pasado nada. Eso sÃ­, se quedÃ³ por espacio de cuarenta minutos la lluvia, pegajosa y molesta para el desarrollo de un juego fluido. Por ello la primera parte fue gris, tanto o mÃ¡s que el cielo. Solo la rasgÃ³ un destello del 'mesÃ­as' blanquiazul SÃ©bastien Haller. El esperado delantero, que debutaba ante su pÃºblico, se hizo con un balÃ³n en el centro del campo y, tras dejar por el camino a varios contrarios que fueron al choque con Ã©l, sirviÃ³ un excelente pase en profundidad para Miguel de la Fuente. Se plantÃ³ este ante el portero, que bloqueÃ³ su disparo. ApareciÃ³ entonces de nuevo Haller para intentar definir con un potente disparo, pero se encontrÃ³ otra vez con Julen Agirrezabala. Fue la ocasiÃ³n mÃ¡s clara de una mitad inicial en la que el Athletic solo creÃ³ peligro de manera tÃ­mida con centros laterales y disparos lejanos. Todo ello lo vio IÃ±aki Williams desde el banquillo, y tambiÃ©n a su hermano Nico renqueante tras un choque con Valentin Rosier en el minuto 43. Se quedÃ³ este Ãºltimo en el vestuario durante el descanso y a los diez minutos de la reanudaciÃ³n irrumpiÃ³ en escena el mayor de la saga. Lo agradeciÃ³ el cuadro rojiblanco, que de su mano mejorÃ³ el aspecto. AÃºn asÃ­, estuvo cerca de encajar el primero cuando un pase al interior del Ã¡rea de Miguel de la Fuente lo desviÃ³ Unai NÃºÃ±ez hacia el palo. Susto aislado para un conjunto visitante mÃ¡s sÃ³lido que poco a poco fue precipitÃ¡ndose sobre el Ã¡rea rival, llamando a una suerte que vino en su auxilio cuando un golpeo de Dani Vivian tras una acciÃ³n de estrategia se introdujo en la porterÃ­a al tocarlo Jorge SÃ¡enz. No se conformÃ³ el equipo bilbaino con mantener su ventaja y acabÃ³ por ampliarla diez minutos mÃ¡s tarde. Lo hizo por medio de IÃ±aki Williams, que se filtrÃ³ con sigilo entre Sergio GonzÃ¡lez y un Renato Tapia convertido en central, para recoger una buena asistencia de Andoni Gorosabel y superar al arquero. Sin nada que perder, se lanzÃ³ el LeganÃ©s a por un tanto que le diera esperanzas. Sin embargo su voluntad chocÃ³ una vez mÃ¡s de bruces contra el poste, esta vez en un tiro de Diego GarcÃ­a. TambiÃ©n se topÃ³ con Ã©l, casi al final, un cabezazo de Gorka Guruzeta. No hubo mucho mÃ¡s y el Athletic se llevÃ³ tres puntos que le dan tranquilidad a costa de un rival que encadena su tercera derrota seguida. - Ficha tÃ©cnica: 0 - LeganÃ©s: Soriano; Rosier, Jorge SÃ¡enz (Tapia, m.71), Nastasic, Sergio GonzÃ¡lez, Franquesa; Brasanac (Juan Cruz, m.71), CissÃ©, Roberto LÃ³pez (Munir, m.78); Haller (Diego GarcÃ­a, m.78) y Miguel de la Fuente. 2 - Athletic: Agirrezabala; Gorosabel, NÃºÃ±ez, Vivian, Yuri; Vesga (Prados, m.56), Ruiz de Galarreta (Ander Herrera, m.62); Berenguer, Unai GÃ³mez (Sancet, m.56), Nico Williams (Guruzeta, m.46); y DjalÃ³ (IÃ±aki Williams, m.56). Goles: 0-1, m.66: Vivian. 0-2, m.76: IÃ±aki Williams. Ãrbitro: Francisco JosÃ© HernÃ¡ndez Maeso (ComitÃ© extremeÃ±o). MostrÃ³ tarjeta amarilla a Miguel de la Fuente (m.41), Rosier (m.63) y Tapia (m.89); jugadores del LeganÃ©s. Incidencias: Partido adelantado de la jornada 7 LaLiga EA Sports disputado en el estadio de Butarque ante 8.304 espectadores. En la previa fue homenajeado y realizÃ³ el saque de honor Javier Eraso, ex jugador de ambos clubes, al que ademÃ¡s se le entregÃ³ una camiseta del conjunto local con el dorsal nÃºmero ocho. En el descanso se homenajeÃ³ tambiÃ©n al tenista Rafa JÃ³dar, vecino de LeganÃ©s y campeÃ³n del US Open Junior, quien recibiÃ³ igualmente una camiseta de manos del presidente Jeff Luhnow y una bandera con el escudo de la ciudad otorgada por el alcalde Miguel Ãngel Recuenco. EnvÃ­a tu noticia a: [participa@andaluciainformacion.es](mailto:participa@andaluciainformacion.es)

author: Danton Unger
title: 'The work is incredibly important': How a Winnipeg woman has been helping in Ukraine
text:
[Skip to main content](#main)
'The work is incredibly important': How a Winnipeg woman has been helping in Ukraine
Home for the holidays has taken on a whole new meaning for a Winnipeg woman who has spent more than a year in Ukraine rebuilding schools and helping students.
When Russia invaded Ukraine, Patricia Maruschak answered the call and headed to Kyiv in October 2022 to help. She works with Finn Church Aid, a Finnish humanitarian organization that provides education support in emergencies.
On her way to Ukraine, she said Russia bombed the centre of Kyiv, killing several people.
"That hadn't happened for a long time since the war started. I think it was quite shocking and it was a little bit of a surprise to myself, my family was a little bit concerned," she told CTV News.
But she noticed something else in Ukraine too â€“ resilience.
"Entering into Ukraine by train, you see that despite the fact that it's a country in the middle of a full-blown war, I mean life does go on, people do continue with their everyday normal lives," she said.
"They persevere despite some difficult and uncertain conditions."
Maruschak heads up Finn Church Aid's office in Ukraine. She and her team work to reopen schools that have been damaged in bombings. Students in Ukraine can't go to school unless it has a functioning bomb shelter, so that is another priority Maruschak tackles.
Her work goes beyond the school's brick-and-mortar, focussing on the staff and students inside.
"They often have to deal with children who have been through some traumatic things, or who have parents who maybe are fighting at the front, or maybe some have even been taken prisoner of war," she said.
"We try to help them with some psychosocial support, coping mechanisms, and skills as well."
It is work that Maruschak has made personal sacrifices to do. While working in Ukraine, she has had to leave her husband and two children behind in Winnipeg.
"It's still a big change, the fact that she's not here, and then also worrying about what's going on over there, especially when you hear about air raids and alarms and that type of thing," her husband Keith Swinton said.
But the family strives to include each other in their everyday lives even though they are on different continents most of the year.
"If you see a deer on the street, you can photograph it and send it to her," Keith said. "Just including her a bit more in the day-to-day."
Still, her family is proud of the work she is doing.
"She's an incredible woman. She's got a unique set of talents and abilities and experience that just led to this. And the work is incredibly important," Keith said.
"It's important for people to remember what's going on there, that every day children are being affected. Children are dying as a result of Russian bombs in an absolutely senseless war that Ukraine didn't start."
Maruschak has been home in Winnipeg with her family for the holidays, but she says it has been a shift.
The sounds of explosions and anti-aircraft gunfire â€“ a part of everyday life in parts of Ukraine â€“ are hard to leave behind.
"I also have an air raid alarm app that is on and will tell me when there's an air raid alarm happening," she said. "I still see the notifications, but to just try and go back to a life where that's not a part of the daily reality."
Maruschak is planning to return to Ukraine to continue her work following a Ukrainian Christmas celebration with her family.

author: Selome Hailu
title: 'The 1% Club' Moves to Fox for Season 2, Joel McHale to Host
text:
Quiz competition series â€œThe 1% Clubâ€ has been renewed for a second season, which will air on Fox after previously streaming on Amazon Prime Video. Joel McHale will host Season 2, taking over from Patton Oswalt.
Each episode of â€œThe 1% Clubâ€ begins with 100 contestants who face elimination as they answer a series of questions meant to measure logic, reasoning skills and common sense. They strive to make it to the end and win a $100,000 prize by answering a question only 1% of the country can get right.
Based on an international format created by Dean Nabarro and Andy Auerbach, â€œThe 1% Clubâ€ is produced by BBC Studios Los Angeles Productions and Magnum Media, with BBC Studios distributing. Executive producers include Nabarro and Auerbacfor Magnum as well as Ryan Oâ€™Dowd and Krystal Whitney for BBC. Wes Kauble serves as showrunner. The original version of â€œThe 1% Clubâ€ began airing on the U.K.â€™s ITV in 2022, and BBC has since launched the format in Netherlands, Australia, Germany, France, Israel, Spain, Turkey, Mexico, Greece, Ukraine and Hungary along with the U.S.
McHale is best known for leading the NBC sitcom â€œCommunityâ€ as Jeff Winger from 2009 to 2015, as well as for hosting several unscripted programs, most notably â€œThe Soupâ€ on E! from 2004 to 2015. Currently, he hosts the E! reality competition series â€œHouse of Villainsâ€ and Foxâ€™s baking competition series â€œCrime Scene Kitchen.â€ He also stars as Frank Shaw in the Fox sitcom â€œAnimal Control,â€ which is currently on its third season.
McHale is repped by UTA, Ziffren Brittenham and Johnson Shapiro Slewett Kole.
â€œJoelâ€™s outstanding comedic timing and hosting charm already make him a standout talent here at Fox, and now â€” building on â€œThe 1% Clubâ€â€˜s strong first year on the network â€” weâ€™re bringing his unrivaled energy, irreverence and charisma to Season 2,â€ said Michael Thorn, president of Fox Television Network. â€œWe look forward to expanding on our successful relationship with Joel and continuing our partnership with the incredible production teams at BBC Studios and Magnum.â€
â€œI am 1,000,000% excited to be partnering with Fox to host â€œThe 1% Club,â€ said Joel McHale. â€œI absolutely love the show and love the game play to the 10 ğ‘¥ and guarantee my hair, makeup and wardrobe will look great at least 68% of the time.â€
â€œ99% of us are unfortunately not as funny as Joel McHale, which makes him the perfect host for â€˜The 1% Club.â€™ His unmatched approach to comedy is innately unpredictable and will take audiences on a thrill-ride as they watch him in action with our contestants, striving to put their wits to the test,â€ said Ryan Oâ€™Dowd, president of unscripted at BBC Studios Los Angeles Productions . â€œâ€™The 1% Clubâ€™ has proven to be a massive global hit, and we couldnâ€™t be more thrilled to partner with Rob Wade, Michael Thorn and the talented and passionate team at Fox who believe in this show and in our shared vision for this new season.â€

author: VNExplorer
title: Good Friday marked across Australia with church services, Easter egg hunts, and seafood spreads
text:
The Good Friday service at EFKS Southwest Brisbane drew churchgoers dressed in white. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)
Locals have gathered across the country to mark Good Friday this Easter long weekend.
From special church services, to family days out in the sun, and seafood-rich dishes â€” hereâ€™s how youâ€™re spending the public holiday.
â€˜Blessedâ€™ churchgoers gather in Brisbane In Brisbane, dozens of churchgoers at EFKS Southwest Brisbane dressed in white and gathered at the Samoan Church to celebrate Good Friday.
In Samoan culture, traditionally, white is worn during the Easter period.
â€œFor us, white represents a new life in our culture; itâ€™s such a significant day, so we wear white clothes,â€ churchgoer Vao said.
The Queensland service consisted of hymns, singing and prayer.
Rosie Alaalatoa, who attended the service, said it was a â€œblessingâ€ to embrace culture and language.
â€œItâ€™s a special day for all of us in the Samoan community; we come together and worship, and weâ€™re able to see each other,â€ she said.
â€œThis is a beautiful day for the islanders.â€
Anglican Church Southern Queensland Archbishop Jeremy Greaves said in his Good Friday message, â€œno matter how desperate things seem, it does get betterâ€.
â€œLove will endure. Hope will win out,â€ he said.
Archbishop Greaves said he hoped people could use the Easter break to find strength, hope and courage to â€œsing alleluiaâ€ in the face of â€œthe darkness of the worldâ€.
Calls for harmony in Sydney At the St Patrickâ€™s Cathedral in Western Sydney, hundreds gathered to pray through the Stations of the Cross, marking the different phases of Jesusâ€™s life and death.
Bishop Vincent Long led the procession.
He began with an Easter message calling for harmony in the Israel-Gaza war, which has been front-of-mind for many in the local community.
Pilgrimage across Melbourne Melbourne Christians also marked Good Friday, by participated in the annual Way of the Cross walk.
Hundreds began the walk at one of Melbourneâ€™s oldest churches, St Francis on Lonsdale Street, and concluded at St Paulâ€™s Cathedral on Flinders Street.
The walk takes Christians of different denominations on a journey through Melbourneâ€™s city centre, stopping at many of the cityâ€™s historic churches to share reflections, songs, and prayers.
The annual pilgrimage has been running since 1998.
It passes from church to church, commemorating Jesusâ€™s journey from the Last Supper to the crucifixion and resurrection.
Followers were invited to continue the walk when it resumed early on Easter Sunday.
Easter egg hunt in Hobart Meanwhile, Tasmanians marked Good Friday with an Easter egg hunt for the kids.
Around 2,000 children and their parents took part in the annual egg hunt and family picnic at the Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens.
Clues to find a special chocolate Easter egg surprise were hidden throughout the gardens.
It is the 12th year the event has been hosted, which raises funds for medical research across Tasmania.
Seafood spreads in Perth Over in Western Australia, many are eagerly lining up at the fish markets to score a fresh catch for their Good Friday feast.
Richard Karaganiaâ€™s religious background means itâ€™s important to him and his wife â€” who is Catholic â€” to avoid red meat on Good Friday, so he was at the fish market bright and early on Friday.
â€œItâ€™s all very nice, a tomatoey fish stew,â€ he said of the fish fillet and extra-large prawns he was picking up.
â€œBut also itâ€™s a nice time of the year to sit outside and have a seafood meal.â€
Third-generation fishmonger Matt Kailis said the most important thing is to look for this Good Friday is local produce.
â€œWeâ€™ve got all variety of fish to suit basically any budget and any cooking style,â€ he said.
â€œTraditionally people might have just bought their snapper, but theyâ€™re trying a lot of different species of fish, theyâ€™re more adventurous in their cooking.â€

author: Patricia Holbrook
title: Focusing on unconditional gratitude for the new year
text:
The Rev. George Matheson was a 19th-century Scottish minister, hymn writer and accomplished author. At the age of 17, Matheson started losing his eyesight and was deemed fully blind at the age of 20. Despite the hardships brought on by blindness, Matheson graduated first in his class at the University of Glasgow and became a clergyman. He dedicated his life to ministering to others through his sermons, writings, and theological and historical studies.
In his book, â€œMoments on the Mount,â€ now out of print, Matheson wrote a meditation on the value of his affliction â€” a prayer that reflects a heart seeking to live a life of unconditional gratitude:
â€œMy God, I have never thanked you for my â€˜thorn.â€™ I have thanked you a thousand times for my roses but never once for my â€˜thorn.â€™ I have been looking forward to a world where I shall get compensation for my cross as itself a present glory. Teach me the glory of my cross; teach me the value of my â€˜thorn.â€™ Show me that I have climbed to you by the path of pain. Show me that my tears have made my rainbow.â€
The â€œthornâ€ in Mathesonâ€™s prayer refers to the Apostle Paulâ€™s writing in the 12th chapter of his second letter to the Corinthian church, where he writes about a disease or hardship he endured. He called it his â€œthorn in the flesh.â€ The apostle pleaded with God to remove this affliction three times, and Godâ€™s answer and the apostleâ€™s response echo the sentiment in Mathesonâ€™s prayer:
â€œAnd (God) said to me, â€˜My grace is sufficient for you, for my strength is made perfect in weakness.â€™ Therefore, most gladly I will rather boast in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me. Therefore, I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in needs, in persecutions, in distresses, for Christâ€™s sake. For when I am weak, then I am strong.â€
The week between Christmas and New Yearâ€™s Day is often used as a time to inventory the year that comes to an end. For many years, I have used this week to look back, rejoice in the yearâ€™s accomplishments, and acknowledge where changes need to happen before establishing goals for the new year.
During this time, I also ask God to give me a word and a Bible verse to focus on for the next 365 days.
As I prayed for 2024, the word â€œgratitudeâ€ rested in my spirit, and the verse that came to mind is found in Paulâ€™s first letter to the church in Thessalonica, chapter 5:
â€œRejoice always, pray without ceasing, in everything give thanks; for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus for you.â€
For the past couple of months, this mindset of unconditional gratitude has repeatedly come into focus during my devotion time.
This year has undoubtedly brought many moments of joy, but it has also brought about difficult circumstances that escape my control. I have found myself crying out to God for deliverance and heard in response the same words that the apostle Paul highlighted throughout his writings. â€œBe thankful.â€ â€œRejoice.â€ â€œMy grace is sufficient.â€
It is so easy to thank God for the beautiful things that have happened in the year that is coming to an end. But to thank him for tribulations can feel like calling pain pleasurable. An oxymoron indeed, until we grasp the importance of changing our perspective concerning difficult circumstances from what we see (or feel) to what God can see and wants to accomplish in and through us.
Where we see pain, God sees a purpose in the making. Where we see painful waiting, he sees our faith in his promises.
Gratitude is not a feeling. It is an attitude of the heart. It is a deliberate choice. Unconditional gratitude is born when we understand, as Matheson did, that God desires to make rainbows out of our tears and teach us that it is only through our weaknesses that we experience his strength and grace.
